body.head: NAF000367
body.p: They formerly, ǂkágáraA bird [it] is; a little bird [it] is; it resembles the Lanius Collaris [a Butcher-Bird]. formerly went to fetch his younger sister, he went to take her away; he went to take her away from ǃhaũnuA man [it] is; the Rain [it] is. I think that a Rain's Sorcerer [he] seems to have been. His name resembles [that of] the mucus which we are used to blow out of our nose, which is thick, that which the Bushmen call ǃhaũǃhaũŋg.; and he took [her] back to her parents.
ǃhaũnu gave chase to his brother-in-law, he passed along behind the hill.
The clouds came, clouds which were unequalled in beauty [lit. "clouds which not beautiful like them"]; they vanished away.

ǂkágára said:To his younger sister. "Thou must walk on." His younger sister walked, carrying [a heavy burden of]
things, [her] husband's things. He [ǂkágára] said: "Thou must walk on; for, home is not near at hand."
The clouds came, the clouds vanished away.

ǂkágára said: "Thou must walk on, for, thou art the one who dost see." And he, because the house became near, he exclaimed: "Walk on! Walk on!" He waited for his younger sister; his younger sister came up to his side. He exclaimed: "What thingsThe things which the wife carried, they resembled water; they, in this manner, were pushing at her; while they felt that they were not hard, they did in this manner [i.e. swayed forward], behind her back. can these be, which thou dost heavily carry?"

Then ǃháũnu sneezed, on account of it;ǃhaũnu was the one from whose nostrils blood came out, when he intended to sneeze. He sneezed on account of his things, to which ǂkágára did in this manner [i.e. felt at roughly]. blood poured out of his nostrils; he stealthily lightened at his brother-in-law. His brother-in-law fended him quickly off,In the word ǁkhábbe(t) the t is barely pronounced. The meaning of this word is explained by the narrator as follows: [He] fends off his brother-in-law [by motioning with his arm]. Fending off [it] is, when other people are fighting their fellows with their fists. Fending off is that which they are wont to do, they wave off with the arm, while they fend off the other one's arm. He [ǂkágára] fended off the other one's lightning. his brother-in-law also stealthily lightened at him. He quickly fended off his brother-in-law. His brother-in-law also lightened at him. He [ǂkágára] said: "Thou must come [and] walk close beside me; for, thou art the one who dost see that husband does not allow us time; for, he does not singly lighten."

They [ǂkágára and ǃhaũnu] went along angry with
each other. ǃhaũnu had intended that he should be the one lightening to ǂkágára to whisk away ǂkágára. ǂkágára was one who was strong [lit. "was not light", or "did not feel light"], he continued to fend off his younger sister's husband, ǃhaũnu. His younger sister's husband was also lightening at him; he was lightening at his brother-in-law. Then he stealthily lightened at his younger sister's husband with black lightning,Black lightning is that which kills us, that which we do not perceive it come; it resembles a gun, we are merely startled by the clouds' thundering, while the other man lies, shrivelled up lies. he, lightening, whisked him up [and carried him to a little distance].

His younger sister's husband, in this manner, lay dying; he, in this manner, he thundered,As he lay while ǂkágára bound up his headHis head ached; his head was splitting [with pain]. with the net, he, returning, arrived at home.

He went to lie down in the hut, while ǃhaũnu lay thundering;To thunder is ǃkụérrītẹn; but the narrator explained that ǃkĕǃkéya tà here means 'to lie thundering'; and illustrated the expression by saying that "the Bushmen are wont to say that the springbok is one which goes to lie bleating; it is not willing to die quickly". he thundered there, while ǂkágára went to lie down, when he had rubbed them [i.e. himself and his younger sister] with buchu,Buchu (in Webster's international Dictionary of 1902) is stated to be, "A South African shrub (Barosma)". buchu, buchu, buchu, he lay down.
My grandmothers used to say: "ǂkágára and his companion are those who fight in the East, he and ǃhaũnu."

When the clouds were thick, and the clouds, when the clouds were thick, and the clouds were at this place, and the clouds resembled a mountain, then, the clouds were lightening, on account of it. And my grandmothers used to say: "It is ǂkágára, with ǃhaũnu."
